p.s: Worne starts his article with the statement can't, won't, don't, three words wichwhich sum up out national view on speaking foreign languages(l. 1-2).
With this statement he want'swants to present to the reader the problem the UK has when it comes to foreign languages.
In the next sentence he underlines his statement with the fact that the number of UK students choosing to study foriegn languages at university level has been in steady decline (l. 3-4).
This underlines his statement that less students are willing to study foreign languages.
In line 6 he uses the metaphor that languages are now on the menu in more primary schools to point out that the system is trying to fix the problem.
But he adds that there is a long haul ahead (l. 7).
Moreover in the next sentence he says that the uptake of languages at both the GCSE and A-level has also stalled (l. 7-8).
This underlines that it is up to the young people to change that.
WornWorne gives the reader'sreaders some numbers, in fact that 10.000 fewer language A-level exams were taken last year than at the end of the 1990s (l. 9-10).
This again points out that there is a big problem when it comes to language.
He uses sarcasm to criticise the statements or facts that underline that it is not so important to learn foreign languages.

For example he comments the statement that Everyone speaks English in the world of business (l. 12) with they don't (l. 13) or that your iPhone will now translate road signs for you (l. 13) with but you may crash or choke on the roaming data charges (l. 14).

To finish his criticcritique he says that the next generation of wearable tech will enable intercultural telepathy anyway (l. 14-15) wichwhich is also sarcasm to show that for globalisation foreign language is very important.
He comments the whole paragraph with cobblers (l. 15).
To point out how important language learning and language itself is he uses a paralelismparallelism in line 16 and 17.
Language learning is vital(l. 16) and Languages are essential (l. 17).
He connects an enumeration to the parallelism to show what language is so important for for our trade, prosperity, cultural exports, diplomacy and national security (l. 17-18).
From line 19-23 he outlines that UK businesses need foreign language skills (l. 20) but he also points out that many UK businesses [...] rely on translators or hire abroad.
With the personification forward-thinking universities (l. 24) he underlines that it important for the future of the UK that young people learn foreign languages.
To show the advantage of learning foreign languages he says that a lawyer with Chinese language skills is more in demand than a pure lawyer or a pure linguist (l. 28-29).

At the end of the article he reaches out to the reading parents and uses the metaphor essential strings to our childrenschildren's bows (l. 34) to make clear that it is important that students learn foreign langauges.
